content: D&D miniatures paper or plastic I have been asked so many times why Jeremy on
all that cool terrain that you build do you use paper minis why don't you use 3d
minis they're so much better first of all don't be a jerk
nobody likes jokes this is my story I decided to start playing and running D&D
year and a half ago something like that I'm new to the Hobby instantly when
deciding to do this I knew I wanted to use epic game tables with cool props and
maps and all the whole thing I had never done any of it before but I was
confident that I could figure out how to build cool stuff
the terrain part of it I was ready to go I was not intimidated by it whatsoever
but minis that's a different story first of all the skill required to start
painting minis versus the skill required to start building stuff like terrain a
lot different there is a higher learning curve on painting minis and I was aware
of that so that was a little bit intimidating but the main reason I went
to paper minis from the beginning was cost and time I was new to the Hobby I
didn't have a decade's worth of collection of minis to pull from I was
starting at 0 I was about to start a campaign that I wanted to be really cool
so I needed a whole bunch of minis and it just wasn't realistic to buy all of
them at once and paint them I decided to do it a simpler way with paper
and I kind of messed around and I figured out how to do it I have a
background in graphic design so I that part of it made it really easy where I
could Google image search for exactly what I wanted and easily edit it and
format it to the right size and get it printed the other question that I guess
get us even more like literally all the time is how do I make my paper minis why
don't you make a video tutorial about paper minis the reason I haven't made a
video on how to make them is because somebody else already did and they did
an awesome job my friend why lock a long time ago made a video
about paper Mining's and he covers it in great detail and if you haven't seen
that video and you want to make paper minis check the links below to his
tutorial on that it's fantastic it's got you covered
now paper versus plastic pros and cons I am going to say that overall paper minis
have far more pros than 3d minutes however the one or two pros of 3d minis
do have an argument for trumping all the other pros I know this is a touchy
subject for some of you and if you want to argue about what you think is better
I mean go nuts but the whole point of this is that do whatever works for your
group and your table and work within your constraints both timewise
budget-wise skill wise paper mini pros cheap as hell like for the cost of one
reaper bones 3d mini which is already an affordable one I can print like a
hundred paper minis factor in the cost of washers for bases and okay maybe like
50 minis to one you can't beat the cost if you want to argue about cost your
silly paper wins hi same thing man the time it takes to do paper menus
and hand down there is some about time that takes place for searching for
imagery and editing it it doesn't take that long actually making them you can
make 20 some-odd paper minis based and done and ready for the table in one
evening so no question paper may need to win on time
the third Pro of paper menus and I think this is the most important one for me is
the fact that you can always have the exact mini that you need if you need
some very specific miniature you can find that art online I guarantee it you
can find it and can't find it you can find something that's close that you can
edit with 3d minis well first of all a mini might not even exist for what you
want and even if it does then you got to buy it or a whole bunch of it looks
expensive if you are writing your adventure day or two before or your
session and you need a whole bunch of cockroach monsters slimy cockroach
answers where you're going to get a mini oh that day and paint it and have it
ready you're not but you know what you find the art online and you can edit it
you can get things printed and you put it on a base and you're ready to go boom
always got the right mini for the job I think that a lot of people dislike paper
menus because I think it takes away from the overall feel of the training of this
beautiful train then you have a paper mini on it and that takes away from it
what I think takes away from it is having a goblin and telling your players
oh this isn't actually Colin this is it's actually like a closet I just don't
have costed mini so just pretend er that takes away from it this is an
imagination based game we play friends that's not the part I want my players
imagining I want the mini to look correct so that is the things that
loveable paper menus but what do I dislike well one they don't look is cool
no argument there and two they look cool faced on
but they look the same on both sides so there's no front and back there's ways
you can correct that with printing blanks on the back but I don't really
like the way that looks either and when you turn it it looks sad
you got the skinny little skinny little thing like it's like it doesn't even
exist however 3d minis well expensive hard to
get the right ones you want to take a lot of times it takes a bunch of scale
but goddamn they look cool they really do they look so much cooler on the table
I'm not even argue that they look great I have an awesome tactile feel to them
to integrate into 3d terrain a little bit better aesthetically they blend a
little bit better directionality is always perfect you know where that mini
is looking you know what's the back you know what's the side it all makes sense
I've got hundreds of paper minis I love them but eventually this urge for real
minis took hold and so I finally got them and I figured you know I'm not
going to get every monster I need but I could get my player party for a year my
players have been playing with these paper minis and they were great and I
love them but I decided to splurge and upgrade I finally transitioned to the 3d
minis for my party and had a blast painting them it was really fun and I
really enjoy using them but am I going to transition is a 3d minis exclusively
not a freaking chance no way I won't that time for that and like I said it's
important that my minis are always right so I'm a slowly build on my collection
getting the essential but the point of the story is both work pick whatever
works for you and don't let anybody tell you that your way is wrong and don't
ever feel like your paper minis are not good enough because they are
if you're a good VM and you run a good game it doesn't matter what many of you
use as long as they get the job done if you want to get started using paper
minis I'm not making a tutorial because like I said why lock already did and
it's great the only thing that I will add to it
I personally don't print my paper minis at home I got a crappy printers they
don't come out looking good enough and inks expensive I get my printed at
Staples so one cheats that can fit a dozen or so minis on it cost me 89 cents
and that's because I print it on 12-point glossy cover stop it is the
thickest paper that they print on the detail the resolution of their printers
is phenomenal the images look excellent and the cardstock once it folded in half
and glued is very stiff they're very very rigid and the glossy paper really
looks good so that is what I will add on top of while ox already excellent
tutorial those are my thoughts on miniatures feel free to argue in the
comments below try not to be addressed
